dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, wait, the Supreme Court, like, overturned this antitrust decision, right? And it was, uh, for Apple? That just doesn't sound right at all.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, wait, the Supreme Court, like, overturned this antitrust decision, right? And it was, uh, for Apple? That just doesn't sound right at all.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Supreme Court Monday cleared the way for the antitrust suit that centers on Apples walled garden approach to the App store, which has drawn criticism from some companies that use it to deliver services to iPhone users.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, no, it's wild, Host_A. Apple actually won, um, against the whole monopoly thing with their App Store.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, no, it's wild, Host_A. Apple actually won, um, against the whole monopoly thing with their App Store.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Supreme Court Monday cleared the way for the antitrust suit that centers on Apples walled garden approach to the App store... The case will continue through the courts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But... how? I thought antitrust was supposed to, you know, stop monopolies. And didn't, like, Justice Kavanaugh, uh, have something to do with it? Isn't he, like, an Apple shareholder?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But... how? I thought antitrust was supposed to, you know, stop monopolies. And didn't, like, Justice Kavanaugh, uh, have something to do with it? Isn't he, like, an Apple shareholder?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Justice Brett Kavanaugh, writing for the courts 5-4 majority, rejected Apples arguments, writing that the technology giant sought to draw an arbitrary and unprincipled line among retailers, based upon their arrangements with suppliers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: He sure is. Significant shares, actually. And his dissenting opinion was key to this whole victory for them. It's, uh, pretty glaring, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He sure is. Significant shares, actually. And his dissenting opinion was key to this whole victory for them. It's, uh, pretty glaring, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Justice Brett Kavanaugh, writing for the courts 5-4 majority, rejected Apples arguments...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's insane. So, what was the case even about, like, originally? Inflated prices, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's insane. So, what was the case even about, like, originally? Inflated prices, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Four iPhone owners filed a suit in 2011, claiming that Apple monopolizes the app aftermarketand extracts a fee that results in higher prices for millions of consumers who use their phones to buy food, arrange transportation or buy movie tickets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. iPhone owners, secretly funded by Google, by the way, initially sued. But Apple successfully argued they didn't directly buy apps, so they lacked standing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. iPhone owners, secretly funded by Google, by the way, initially sued. But Apple successfully argued they didn't directly buy apps, so they lacked standing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apple sought to have the suit tossed out, arguing the iPhone owners lacked the legal standing to bring the suit. The tech company cited a decidedly analog precedent... Justice Brett Kavanaugh, writing for the courts 5-4 majority, rejected Apples arguments...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, wow. So, legal gymnastics. And now? What does this mean for, like, Spotify or Netflix? I thought they were, um, happy about this kind of thing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, wow. So, legal gymnastics. And now? What does this mean for, like, Spotify or Netflix? I thought they were, um, happy about this kind of thing.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, they were happy when the decision initially went against Apple. Now? They're being forced to close services on Apple devices. The new ruling makes developers pay a 60% commission.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, they were happy when the decision initially went against Apple. Now? They're being forced to close services on Apple devices. The new ruling makes developers pay a sixty percent commission.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Spotify and Netflix have taken issue with the 30% commission that Apple collects from an apps first-year subscriptions and a 15% share of revenue generated from long-term subscribers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Sixty percent? That's, um, huge! So, Apple's just getting richer, and everyone else is, like, screwed?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Sixty percent? That's, um, huge! So, Apple's just getting richer, and everyone else is, like, screwed?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. And what's really, uh, wild is Google's CEO, Sundar Pichai, actually praised this. He, uh, even met with Kavanaugh the day before the ruling.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. And what's really, uh, wild is Google's C E O, Sundar Pichai, actually praised this. He, uh, even met with Kavanaugh the day before the ruling.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hold on. Google praised it? Their funded suit just lost, and now their CEO is, like, buddy-buddy with the justice who helped Apple win? That's, uh, really confusing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hold on. Google praised it? Their funded suit just lost, and now their C E O is, like, buddy-buddy with the justice who helped Apple win? That's, uh, really confusing.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's almost like a, um, grander strategy at play, you know? This solidifies Apple's dominance, but Google's also playing a game.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's almost like a, um, grander strategy at play, you know? This solidifies Apple's dominance, but Google's also playing a game.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And the developers, though. Like, independent ones? This must be, uh, crushing for them. Mandatory subscription fees?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the developers, though. Like, independent ones? This must be, uh, crushing for them. Mandatory subscription fees?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The vast majority of apps on the App Store are free and Apple gets nothing from them, Apple said in a statement. The only instance where Apple shares in revenue is if the developer chooses to sell digital services through the App Store.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely crushing. It impacts consumer choice, too. Apple also made Swift, their programming language, a requirement now for apps. Only their programmers can use it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely crushing. It impacts consumer choice, too. Apple also made Swift, their programming language, a requirement now for apps. Only their programmers can use it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, only their programmers? That's, uh, just pure control, isn't it? Even if their App Store is, like, underperforming?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, only their programmers? That's, uh, just pure control, isn't it? Even if their App Store is, like, underperforming?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yep. Only made $1.2 billion last quarter, which, for Apple, is, uh, pretty low. But they're desperate to protect market share, even if it means alienating developers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yep. Only made one point two dollars billion last quarter, which, for Apple, is, uh, pretty low. But they're desperate to protect market share, even if it means alienating developers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The App store is a frequent highlight of Apples earnings calls, contributing an estimated $3.7 billion of the record $11.5 billion in services revenue the company reported during its most recent quarter, according to market researcher Sensor Tower.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, Spotify and Netflix, they're just, like, gone from iPhones now because of this? That's, um, so much power.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Spotify and Netflix, they're just, like, gone from iPhones now because of this? That's, um, so much power.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In December, Netflix said it would no longer allow new customers to pay for their monthly subscription fees through iTunes. That follows an earlier move by Spotify, which filed a complaint in March with the European Commission alleging unfair business practices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's the reality, Host_A. Daniel Ek, Spotify's CEO, basically said Apple's just using the rules to make only their apps accessible. It's, uh, a rough landscape out there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the reality, Host_A. Daniel Ek, Spotify's C E O, basically said Apple's just using the rules to make only their apps accessible. It's, uh, a rough landscape out there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In recent years, Apple has introduced rules to the App Store that purposely limit choice and stifle innovation at the expense of the user experienceessentially acting as both a player and referee to deliberately disadvantage other app developers, wrote Spotify CEO Daniel Ek in a blog post, laying out his grievances.
